translated: “When a bhikkhu is virtuous…and seeing fear in the slightest fault, he trains by undertaking the training precepts, this is a nutriment for the arising of the unarisen enlightenment factor of mindfulness and for the fulfilment by development of the arisen enlightenment factor of mindfulness.

original: Puna caparaṁ, subhūti, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo; ye te dhammā🔽ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ
analyzed: puna capara subhūti bhikkhu bahu ssutaḥ hoti suta dharaḥ suta sannicayaḥ ye te dhammā  ādi kalyāṇā majjhe kalyāṇā pariyosāna kalyāṇā sa attham sa byañjanam kevala paripuṇṇam parisuddha
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu is learned, one who has retained and stored up what he has learned.

original: brahmacariyaṁ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā
analyzed: brahmacariyam abhivadanti tathārūpāssa dhammāḥ bahu sutāḥ honti dhātā vacasā paricitā
translated: Those teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, which proclaim the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life—such teachings as these he has learned much of, retained in mind, recited verbally, mentally investigated, and penetrated well by view.

original: manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
analyzed: manasā an upekkhitā diṭṭhiyā su paṭividdhā
translated: and he has well-penetrated views.

original: Yampi, subhūti, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti …pe… diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā, idampi, subhūti, saddhassa saddhāpadānaṁ hoti.
analyzed: yam pi subhūti bhikkhu bahu ssutaḥ hoti pe diṭṭhiyā su paṭividdhā idam pi subhūti saddhassa saddhā apadānam hoti
translated: When a monk is learned … and has well-penetrated views, this is a support for the true Teaching.

original: Puna caparaṁ, subhūti, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto hoti kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko.
analyzed: puna capara subhūti bhikkhu kalyāṇa mittaḥ hoti kalyāṇa sahāyaḥ kalyāṇa sampavaṅkaḥ
translated: Furthermore, a monk has good friends, good companions, good comrades.

original: Yampi, subhūti, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto hoti kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko, idampi, subhūti, saddhassa saddhāpadānaṁ hoti.
analyzed: yam pi subhūti bhikkhu kalyāṇa mittaḥ hoti kalyāṇa sahāyaḥ kalyāṇa sampavaṅkaḥ idam pi subhūti saddhassa saddhā apadānam hoti
translated: When a monk has good friends, good companions, good comrades, this is a support for the true Teaching.

original: Puna caparaṁ, subhūti, bhikkhu suvaco hoti sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgato khamo padakkhiṇaggāhī anusāsaniṁ.
analyzed: puna capara subhūti bhikkhu suvacaḥ hoti sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgataḥ khamo padakkhiṇa ggāhī anusāsani
translated: Furthermore, a monk is easy to speak to, possesses qualities that make him easy to speak to, and he is respected and esteemed by his companions in the spiritual life.

original: Yampi, subhūti, bhikkhu suvaco hoti sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgato khamo padakkhiṇaggāhī anusāsaniṁ, idampi, subhūti, saddhassa saddhāpadānaṁ hoti.
analyzed: yam pi subhūti bhikkhu suvacaḥ hoti sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgataḥ khamaḥ padakkhiṇaggāhī anusāsani idam pi subhūti saddhassa saddhā apadānam hoti
translated: When a monk is easy to speak to … and is respected and esteemed by his companions in the spiritual life, this is a support for the true Teaching.

original: Puna caparaṁ, subhūti, bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnaṁ uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni tatra dakkho hoti analaso tatrupāyāya vīmaṁsāya samannāgato alaṁ kātuṁ alaṁ saṁvidhātuṁ.
analyzed: puna ca para subhūti bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnam uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni tatra dakkhaḥ hoti analasaḥ vīmasāya samannāgataḥ alam kātum alam savidhātu
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu is skilled and diligent in the higher training, endowed with the ability to train in the higher training, and he is adept and diligent in attending to the various duties of the Sangha.

original: Yampi, subhūti, bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnaṁ uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni tatra🔽dakkho hoti analaso tatrupāyāya vīmaṁsāya samannāgato alaṁ kātuṁ alaṁ saṁvidhātuṁ,
analyzed: yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnam uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni tatra  dakkhaḥ hoti analasaḥ tatrupāyāya vīmasāya samannāgataḥ alam kātum alam savidhātu
translated: “In that he is skilled and diligent in the higher training, endowed with the ability to train in the higher training, and he is adept and diligent in attending to the various duties of the Sangha,

original: idampi, subhūti, saddhassa saddhāpadānaṁ hoti.🔽Puna caparaṁ, subhūti, bhikkhu dhammakāmo hoti piyasamudāhāro abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷārapāmojjo.
analyzed: idam pi subhūti saddhassa saddhā apadānam hoti  puna capara subhūti bhikkhu dhamma kāmaḥ hoti piya samudāhāraḥ abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷāra pāmojjaḥ
translated: “This is an attribute of one possessed of faith.🔽“Again, a bhikkhu is fond of the Dhamma, greatly devoted to the joy of the Dhamma, and he is a good speaker with a good delivery, gifted with speech that is polished, clear, and articulate, and he instructs, teaches, clarifies, and analyses the Dhamma with reasons and with proofs.

original: Yampi, subhūti, bhikkhu dhammakāmo hoti piyasamudāhāro abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷārapāmojjo, idampi, subhūti, saddhassa saddhāpadānaṁ hoti.
analyzed: yam pi subhūti bhikkhu dhamma kāmaḥ hoti piya samudāhāraḥ abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷāra pāmojjaḥ idam pi subhūti saddhassa saddhā apadānam hoti
translated: “In that he is fond of the Dhamma, greatly devoted to the joy of the Dhamma, and he is a good speaker with a good delivery, gifted with speech that is polished, clear, and articulate, and he instructs, teaches, clarifies, and analyses the Dhamma with reasons and with proofs,🔽“This is an attribute of one possessed of faith.

original: Puna caparaṁ, subhūti, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānāya, kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
analyzed: puna capara subhūti bhikkhu āraddha vīriyaḥ viharati akusalānam dhammānam pahānāya kusalānam dhammānam upasampadāya thāmavā daḷha parakkamaḥ a nikkhitta dhuraḥ kusalesu dhammesu
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu dwells with energy aroused…🔽

original: Yampi, subhūti, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānāya kusalānaṁ🔽dhammānaṁ upasampadāya thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu,
analyzed: yam pi subhūti bhikkhu āraddha vīriyaḥ viharati akusalānam dhammānam pahānāya kusalāna  dhammānam upasampadāya thāmavā daḷha parakkamaḥ a nikkhitta dhuraḥ kusalesu dhammesu
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu dwells with energy aroused…

original: idampi, subhūti, saddhassa saddhāpadānaṁ hoti.
analyzed: idam pi subhūti saddhassa saddhā apadānam hoti
translated: This too is a benefit of confidence.

original: Puna caparaṁ, subhūti, bhikkhu catunnaṁ jhānānaṁ ābhicetasikānaṁ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
analyzed: puna capara subhūti bhikkhu catunnam jhānānam ābhicetasikānam diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārānam nikāma lābhī hoti akiccha lābhī akasira lābhī
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu, with the destruction of the five lower fetters, becomes an attainer of nibbana in the interval…🔽This too is a benefit of confidence.

original: Yampi, subhūti, bhikkhu catunnaṁ jhānānaṁ ābhicetasikānaṁ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, idampi, subhūti, saddhassa saddhāpadānaṁ hoti.
analyzed: yam pi subhūti bhikkhu catunnam jhānānam ābhicetasikānam diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārānam nikāma lābhī hoti akiccha lābhī akasira lābhī idam pi subhūti saddhassa saddhā apadānam hoti
translated: “Subhuti, when a bhikkhu gains at will, without trouble or difficulty, the four jhanas that constitute the higher mind and provide a pleasant abiding here and now, this is an instance of the development of faith in a faithful person.

original: Puna caparaṁ, subhūti, bhikkhu anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati,🔽seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo🔽dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattārīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo🔽jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe
analyzed: puna capara subhūti bhikkhu aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati  sā iyyathidam ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ tisso api jātiyaḥ catasso pi jātiyaḥ pañca api jātiyaḥ  dasa api jātiyaḥ vīsampi jātiyaḥ tisampi jātiyaḥ cattārīsampi jātiyaḥ paññāsampi jātiyaḥ  jāti satam pi jāti sahassam pi jāti sata sahassam pi aneke pi savaṭṭa kappe aneke pi vivaṭṭa kappe
translated: “Subhuti, when a bhikkhu gains at will, without trouble or difficulty, the four jhanas that constitute the higher mind and provide a pleasant abiding here and now, this is an expression of gratitude and thankfulness on the part of the disciple towards the Teacher.🔽“Again, Subhuti, a bhikkhu recollects his manifold past lives, that is, one birth, two five, ten fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, many eons of cosmic contraction, many eons of cosmic expansion, many eons of cosmic contraction and expansion: ‘There I was so named, of such a race, with such an appearance, such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such the end of my life.🔽Passing away from that state, I re-arose there; there too I was so named, of such a race, with such an appearance, such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such the end of my life.

original: anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī
analyzed: aneke pi sa vaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappe amutra asim eva nāmaḥ evaṃgottaḥ eva vaṇṇo evam āhāraḥ eva sukha dukkha ppaṭisavedī
translated: Passing away from that state, I re-arose here.’ Thus he recollects his manifold past lives in their modes and details.

original: evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo
analyzed: evam āyu pariyantaḥ saḥ tatas cutaḥ amutra udapādi eva nāmaḥ evaṅgottaḥ eva vaṇṇaḥ
translated: “Again, with his mind thus concentrated, purified, and bright, unblemished, free from defects, pliant, malleable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines it to the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.🔽He sees beings passing away and re-appearing, inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate. He understands how beings pass on according to their actions thus: ‘These worthy beings who were ill-conducted in body, speech, and mind, revilers of noble ones, wrong in their views, giving effect to wrong view, on the dissolution of the body, after death, have reappeared in a state of deprivation, in a bad destination, in perdition, even in hell;🔽but these worthy beings who were well-conducted in body, speech, and mind, not revilers of noble ones, right in their views, giving effect to right view, on the dissolution of the body, after death, have reappeared in a good destination, even in the heavenly world.’ Thus with the purified divine eye, which surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and re-appearing, inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and he understands how beings pass on according to their actions.

original: evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti.🔽Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.🔽Yampi, subhūti, bhikkhu anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi
analyzed: evam āhāraḥ eva sukha dukkha ppaṭisavedī evam āyu pariyanto saḥ tatas cutaḥ idhu upapanno ti  iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati  yam pi subhūti bhikkhu aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati
translated: ‘I had such form in the past,’ and so on up to ‘I was conscious of such happiness and suffering,’ and so on up to ‘I was conscious of such a life-term.’🔽Thus with their aspects and particulars he recollects his manifold past lives.🔽“And further, Subhuti, when a bhikkhu recollects the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha,🔽

original: jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.🔽Idampi, subhūti, saddhassa saddhāpadānaṁ hoti.
analyzed: jātim dve api jātiyaḥ pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati  idam pi subhūti saddhassa saddhā apadānam hoti
translated: He recollects his manifold past lives, i.e. one birth, two five, ten fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, many eons of cosmic contraction, many eons of cosmic expansion, many eons of cosmic contraction and expansion, ‘There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose here.’ Thus he recollects his manifold past lives in their modes and details.

original: Puna caparaṁ, subhūti, bhikkhu dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte🔽passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage
analyzed: puna capara subhūti bhikkhu dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte  passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage
translated: “And furthermore, with his mind thus concentrated, purified, and bright, unblemished, free from defects, pliant, malleable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines it to the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.

original: satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena
analyzed: satte pajānāti ime vata bhonto sattā kāya duccaritena samannāgatāḥ vacī duccaritena
translated: He sees — by means of the divine eye, purified and surpassing the human — beings passing away and re-appearing, and he discerns how they are inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate in accordance with their kamma: ‘These beings — who were endowed with bad conduct of body, speech, and mind, who reviled the noble ones, held wrong views and undertook actions under the influence of wrong views — with the break-up of the body, after death, have re-appeared in the plane of deprivation, the bad destination, the lower realms, in hell.🔽But these beings — who were endowed with good conduct of body, speech, and mind, who did not revile the noble ones, who held right views and undertook actions under the influence of right views — with the break-up of the body, after death, have re-appeared in the good destinations, in the heavenly world.’ Thus — by means of the divine eye, purified and surpassing the human — he sees beings passing away and re-appearing, and he discerns how they are inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate in accordance with their kamma.🔽“And furthermore, with his mind thus concentrated, purified, and bright, unblemished, free from defects, pliant, malleable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, the monk

original: samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā,
analyzed: samannāgatāḥ manaḥ duccaritena samannāgatāḥ ariyānam upavādakāḥ micchādiṭṭhikāḥ micchādiṭṭhi kamma samādānāḥ
translated: who are endowed with bodily misconduct, endowed with verbal misconduct, who are slanderers of noble ones, of wrong views, who have acquired views by wrong conduct,

original: te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā. Ime vā
analyzed: te kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapannāḥ ime vā
translated: They are reborn in a state of deprivation, in a bad destination, in the nether world, in hell.

original: pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena
analyzed: pana bhonto sattā kāya su caritena samannāgatāḥ vacī su caritena samannāgatāḥ manaḥ su caritena
translated: Or, there are those who are endowed with good bodily conduct, endowed with good verbal conduct, endowed with good mental conduct,

original: samannāgatā ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa
analyzed: samannāgatāḥ ariyānam an upavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā te kāyassa
translated: who do not revile noble ones, who hold right views and undertake actions under the influence of right views.

original: bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena
analyzed: bhedā param maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapannā ati iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena
translated: When their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a good destination, in a heavenly world.’🔽In this way, with his mind well established in the divine eye,

original: atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe,
analyzed: atikkanta mānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe
translated: he sees beings passing away and arising: base and noble, well favored and ill favored, gone to good destinations and to bad destinations.

original: sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
analyzed: sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti
translated: He understands how beings pass on according to their actions.

original: Yampi, subhūti, bhikkhu dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti, idampi, subhūti, saddhassa saddhāpadānaṁ hoti.
analyzed: yam pi subhūti bhikkhu dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena pe yathā kamma upage satte pajānāti idam pi subhūti saddhassa saddhā apadānam hoti
translated: When a bhikkhu knows the minds of other beings and persons, having encompassed them with his own mind, and he sees that they are freed from the taints, this is a fruit of the contemplative life, a reward of the contemplative life, that is more excellent and perfect than the previous ones.

original: Puna caparaṁ, subhūti, bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara subhūti bhikkhu āsavānam khayā anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu, with the destruction of the taints, enters and dwells in the taintless liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, realizing it for himself with direct knowledge.

original: Yampi, subhūti, bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati, idampi, subhūti, saddhassa saddhāpadānaṁ hotī”ti.
analyzed: yam pi subhūti bhikkhu āsavānam khayā pe sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati idam pi subhūti saddhassa saddhā apadānam hoti iti
translated: When a bhikkhu, with the destruction of the taints, enters and dwells in the taintless liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, realizing it for himself with direct knowledge, this is a fruit of the contemplative life, a reward of the contemplative life, that is more excellent and perfect than the previous ones.”

original: Evaṁ vutte āyasmā subhūti bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte āyasmā subhūti bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, the venerable Subhuti said to the Blessed One:

original: “yānimāni, bhante, bhagavatā saddhassa saddhāpadānāni bhāsitāni, saṁvijjanti tāni imassa bhikkhuno, ayañca bhikkhu etesu sandissati.
analyzed: yāni imāni bhante bhagavatā saddhassa saddhā apadānāni bhāsitāni savijjanti tāni imassa bhikkhuno ayaṃ ca bhikkhu etesu sandissati
translated: “Venerable sir, the fruits of the contemplative life declared by the Blessed One as they are, are found in this bhikkhu, and this bhikkhu is found in these fruits.

original: Ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.🔽Ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo; ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā🔽majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ🔽brahmacariyaṁ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā
analyzed: bhante bhikkhu sīlavā hoti pātimokkha savara savutaḥ viharati ācāra gocara sampannaḥ aṇumattesu vajjesu bhaya dassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu  bhante bhikkhu bahu ssutaḥ hoti suta dharaḥ suta sannicayaḥ ye te dhammā ādi kalyāṇā  majjhe kalyāṇā pariyosāna kalyāṇā sa attham sa byañjanam kevala paripuṇṇam parisuddha  brahmacariyam abhivadanti tathārūpāssa dhammāḥ bahu sutāḥ honti dhātā vacasā paricitā
translated: “This monk is virtuous, of correct conduct and resort, and sees danger in what is blameworthy. He undertakes and trains in the training rules.

original: manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.🔽Ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto hoti kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko.
analyzed: manasā an upekkhitā diṭṭhiyā su paṭividdhā  bhante bhikkhu kalyāṇa mittaḥ hoti kalyāṇa sahāyaḥ kalyāṇa sampavaṅkaḥ
translated: “This monk is learned, remembers what he has learned, and accumulates what he has learned. Those teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, which proclaim the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life — such teachings as these he has learned much of, remembered, mastered verbally, investigated with the mind, and penetrated well by view.🔽“This monk has good friends, good companions, good comrades.

original: Ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu suvaco hoti …pe… anusāsaniṁ.
analyzed: bhante bhikkhu su vacaḥ hoti pe anusāsani
translated: “This monk is easy to speak to, possesses qualities that make him easy to speak to, and he is respected, esteemed, honored, venerated, and revered by his friends, companions, and relatives.

original: Ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnaṁ uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni tattha dakkho hoti analaso tatrupāyāya vīmaṁsāya samannāgato alaṁ kātuṁ alaṁ saṁvidhātuṁ.
analyzed: bhante bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnam uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni tattha dakkhaḥ hoti analasaḥ vīmasāya samannāgataḥ alam kātum alam savidhātu
translated: He is skilled and diligent in his duties to his companions in the holy life, both in public and in private.

original: Ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu dhammakāmo hoti piyasamudāhāro abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷārapāmojjo.🔽Ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati …pe… thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
analyzed: bhante bhikkhu dhamma kāmaḥ hoti piya samudāhāraḥ abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷāra pāmojjaḥ  bhante bhikkhu āraddha vīriyaḥ viharati pe thāmavā daḷha parakkamaḥ a nikkhitta dhuraḥ kusalesu dhammesu
translated: He is one who delights in the Dhamma, loves the Dhamma, values the Dhamma, and is devoted to the Dhamma.🔽He is one of joyous wisdom, of swift wisdom, of great wisdom, of wide wisdom, of profound wisdom, of joyous eloquence, of swift eloquence, of abundant eloquence, of profound eloquence.

original: Ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu catunnaṁ jhānānaṁ ābhicetasikānaṁ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.🔽Ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
analyzed: bhante bhikkhu catunnam jhānānam ābhicetasikānam diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārānam nikāma lābhī hoti akiccha lābhī akasira lābhī 🔽bhante bhikkhu aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati seyyathīdam ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyo pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati
translated: He is one who obtains at will, without trouble or difficulty, the four jhanas that constitute the higher mind and provide a pleasant abiding here and now.🔽He recollects his manifold past abodes with their aspects and details.

original: Ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
analyzed: bhante bhikkhu dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena pe yathā kamma upage satte pajānāti
translated: This monk knows the minds of other beings and persons, having encompassed them with his own mind.

original: Ayaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: bhante bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā pe sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati
translated: This monk, by realising for himself with direct knowledge, here and now enters upon and abides in the deliverance of mind and deliverance by wisdom that are taintless with the destruction of the taints.

original: Yānimāni, bhante, bhagavatā saddhassa saddhāpadānāni bhāsitāni, saṁvijjanti tāni imassa bhikkhuno, ayañca bhikkhu etesu sandissatī”ti.
analyzed: yāni imāni bhante bhagavatā saddhassa saddhā apadānāni bhāsitāni savijjanti tāni imassa bhikkhuno ayaṃ ca bhikkhu etesu sandissati iti
translated: These are the things, venerable sir, that the Blessed One has declared to be the bases of support for one of settled mindfulness. These things are found in this monk, and this monk is seen to be endowed with them.”

original: “Sādhu sādhu, subhūti.
analyzed: sādhu sādhu subhūti
translated: “Good, good, Subhuti!

original: Tena hi tvaṁ, subhūti, iminā ca saddhena bhikkhunā saddhiṁ vihareyyāsi.
analyzed: tena hi tva subhūte iminā ca saddhena bhikkhunā saddhim vihareyyāsi
translated: Well then, Subhuti, you should live in association with this faithful monk.🔽And whenever you wish to see the Tathagata, you should approach the Tathagata in association with this faithful monk.”

original: Yadā ca tvaṁ, subhūti, ākaṅkheyyāsi tathāgataṁ dassanāya, iminā saddhena bhikkhunā saddhiṁ upasaṅkameyyāsi tathāgataṁ dassanāyā”ti.🔽Catutthaṁ.
analyzed: yadā ca tva subhūte ākaṅkheyyāsi tathāgatam dassanāya iminā saddhena bhikkhunā saddhim upasaṅkameyyāsi tathāgatam dassanāya ati  catuttha
translated: The fourth section on the faithful monk is finished.🔽The Book of the Fives

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 11.15🔽2. Anussativagga
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya  anussati vagga
translated: The Chapter on Recollection

original: Mettāsutta
analyzed: mettāsutta
translated: Loving-kindness

original: “Mettāya, bhikkhave, cetovimuttiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya ekādasānisaṁsā pāṭikaṅkhā.
analyzed: mettāya bhikkhave cetaḥ vimuttiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya su samāraddhāya ekādasa anisasā pāṭikaṅkhā
translated: “Bhikkhus, when the liberation of mind by loving-kindness is developed, pursued, handed the opportunity, made the vehicle, made the foundation, maintained, consolidated, and properly undertaken, eleven benefits may be expected.

original: Katame ekādasa?🔽Sukhaṁ supati, sukhaṁ paṭibujjhati, na pāpakaṁ supinaṁ passati, manussānaṁ piyo hoti,🔽amanussānaṁ piyo hoti, devatā rakkhanti, nāssa aggi vā visaṁ vā satthaṁ vā kamati,
analyzed: katame ekādasa  sukham supati sukham paṭibujjhati na pāpakam supinam passati manussānam piyaḥ hoti  amanussānam piyaḥ hoti devatāḥ rakkhanti na assa aggi vā visam vā sattham vā kamati
translated: What are the eleven?

original: tuvaṭaṁ cittaṁ samādhiyati, mukhavaṇṇo vippasīdati, asammūḷho kālaṁ karoti, uttari
analyzed: tuvaṭam cittam samādhiyati mukha vaṇṇaḥ vippasīdati asammūḷhaḥ kālam karoti uttari
translated: One sleeps well; one wakes up feeling refreshed; one does not see bad dreams; one is dear to human beings; one is dear to non-human beings; the deities protect one; fire, poison, and weapons do not injure one; one’s mind quickly becomes concentrated; one’s complexion becomes clear; one dies unconfused;

original: appaṭivijjhanto brahmalokūpago hoti.
analyzed: a paṭivijjhantaḥ brahma loka upagaḥ hoti
translated: if one penetrates no further, one is at least headed for the Brahma-world.

original: Mettāya, bhikkhave, cetovimuttiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya ime ekādasānisaṁsā pāṭikaṅkhā”ti.
analyzed: mettāya bhikkhave cetaḥ vimuttiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya su samāraddhāya ime ekādasa anisasā pāṭikaṅkhāti
translated: When the liberation of mind by loving-kindness is developed, pursued, handed the opportunity, made the vehicle, made the foundation, maintained, consolidated, and properly undertaken, these eleven benefits may be expected.”

original: Pañcamaṁ.
analyzed: pañcama
translated: The fifth section on loving-kindness is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 11.16🔽2. Anussativagga
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya  anussati vagga
translated: The Book of the Elevens

original: Aṭṭhakanāgarasutta
analyzed: aṭṭhaka nāgara sutta
translated: With Aṭṭhakanāgara

original: Ekaṁ samayaṁ āyasmā ānando vesāliyaṁ viharati beluvagāmake.
analyzed: ekam samayam āyasmai ānandaḥ vesāliyam viharati beluva gāmake
translated: At one time the Venerable Ānanda was dwelling at Vesālī in the Gabled Hall.

original: Tena kho pana samayena dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro pāṭaliputtaṁ anuppatto hoti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena dasamaḥ gahapati aṭṭhaka nāgaraḥ pāṭaliputtam an uppattaḥ hoti kenacid eva karaṇīyena
translated: Now on that occasion the householder Dasama of the Aṭṭhagāma clan had arrived at Pāṭaliputta on some business.

original: Atha kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro yena kukkuṭārāmo yena aññataro bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho dasamaḥ gahapati aṭṭhaka nāgaraḥ yena kukkuṭārāmaḥ yena aññataraḥ bhikkhu tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā tam bhikkhum etat avoca
translated: Then the householder Dasama of the Aṭṭhagāma clan went to a certain bhikkhu in the Cock’s Park and said to him:

original: “kahaṁ nu kho, bhante, āyasmā ānando etarahi viharati?
analyzed: kaham nu kho bhante āyasmai ānandaḥ etarahi viharati
translated: “Venerable sir, where is the Venerable Ānanda now dwelling?

original: Dassanakāmā hi mayaṁ, bhante, āyasmantaṁ ānandan”ti.
analyzed: dassana kāmāḥ hi bhante āyasmantam ānandanti
translated: For I want to see the Venerable Ānanda.”

original: “Eso, gahapati, āyasmā ānando vesāliyaṁ viharati beluvagāmake”ti.
analyzed: esaḥ gahapati āyasmai ānandaḥ vesāliyam viharati beluva gāmaka iti
translated: “Householder, the Venerable Ānanda is now dwelling at Vesālī in the Gabled Hall.”

original: Atha kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro pāṭaliputte taṁ karaṇīyaṁ tīretvā yena vesālī
analyzed: atha kho dasamaḥ gahapati aṭṭhaka nāgaraḥ pāṭaliputte tam karaṇīyam tīretvā yena vesālī
translated: Then, when he had concluded his business at Pāṭaliputta, the householder Dasama of the Aṭṭhagāma clan went to Vesālī and to the Gabled Hall.

original: beluvagāmako yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ abhivādetvā
analyzed: beluva gāmakaḥ yena āyasmai ānandaḥ tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantam ānandam abhivādetvā
translated: He then approached the Venerable Ānanda, paid homage to him,

original: ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho dasamaḥ gahapati aṭṭhaka nāgaraḥ āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca
translated: and said to him:

original: “atthi nu kho, bhante ānanda, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena🔽ekadhammo sammadakkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato
analyzed: atthi nu kho bhante ānanda tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena  eka dhammaḥ sammad akkhātaḥ yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharato
translated: “Venerable sir, is there one thing taught by the Blessed One …

original: avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṁ gacchanti, ananuppattaṁ
analyzed: a vimuttam vā cittam vimuccati a parikkhīṇāḥ vā āsavāḥ parikkhayam gacchanti an anuppatta
translated: whereby a bhikkhu who develops and cultivates it can realise a wholesome quality higher than human states,

original: vā anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇātī”ti?
analyzed: vai anuttaram yogakkhemam anupāpuṇāti iti
translated: a distinction higher than human states?”🔽“There is, householder.”🔽“What is that one thing?”

original: “Atthi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo🔽sammadakkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṁ
analyzed: atthi kho gahapati tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena eka dhammaḥ  sammad akkhātaḥ yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharataḥ avimutta
translated: “There is, householder, that one thing taught by the Blessed One …

original: vā cittaṁ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṁ gacchanti, ananuppattaṁ vā
analyzed: vā cittam vimuccati a parikkhīṇāḥ vā āsavāḥ parikkhayam gacchanti an anuppattam vā
translated: whereby a bhikkhu who develops and cultivates it can realise a wholesome quality higher than human states,

original: anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇātī”ti.
analyzed: anuttaram yogakkhemam anupāpuṇāti iti
translated: a distinction higher than human states.”

original: “Katamo pana, bhante ānanda, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena
analyzed: katamaḥ pana bhante ānanda tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena
translated: “But, venerable Ānanda, what is that Dhamma exposition taught by the Blessed One who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened …🔽

original: ekadhammo sammadakkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato🔽avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṁ gacchanti, ananuppattaṁ🔽vā anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇātī”ti?
analyzed: eka dhammaḥ sammad akkhātaḥ yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharato  a vimuttam vā cittam vimuccati a parikkhīṇāḥ vā āsavāḥ parikkhayam gacchanti an anuppatta  vai anuttaram yogakkhemam anupāpuṇāti iti
translated: “But, venerable Ānanda, what is that one thing rightly expounded by the Blessed One … that a bhikkhu who develops and cultivates it can expect …”

original: “Idha, gahapati, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: idha gahapati bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Here, householder, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhāna, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

original: So iti paṭisañcikkhati:🔽‘idampi kho paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ’.
analyzed: saḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati  idam api kho paṭhamam jhānam
translated: He considers this and understands it thus:🔽‘This first jhāna is conditioned and volitionally produced.

original: ‘Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ, tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: yam kho pana kiñci tat aniccam nirodha dhammanti pajānāti
translated: But whatever is conditioned and volitionally produced is subject to destruction, fading away, and cessation.’

original: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti;
analyzed: saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti
translated: Standing upon that, he attains the destruction of the taints.

original: no ce āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
analyzed: no ce āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti tena iva dhamma rāgena tāya dhamma nandiyā pañcannam orambhāgiyānam sayojanānam parikkhayā opapātikaḥ hoti tattha parinibbāyī an āvatti dhammo tasmā lokā
translated: If he does not attain the destruction of the taints, then because of that desire for the Dhamma, that delight in the Dhamma, with the destruction of the five lower fetters he becomes one due to reappear spontaneously in the Pure Abodes and there attain final Nibbana without ever returning from that world.

original: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo🔽sammadakkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṁ🔽vā cittaṁ vimuccati, aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṁ gacchanti, ananuppattaṁ vā
analyzed: ayam pi kho gahapati tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena eka dhammaḥ  sammad akkhātaḥ yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharataḥ avimutta  vā cittam vimuccati a parikkhīṇāḥ vā āsavāḥ parikkhayam gacchanti an anuppattam vā
translated: “This, householder, is the other one thing

original: anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇāti.
analyzed: anuttaram yogakkhemam anupāpuṇāti
translated: that was proclaimed by the Blessed One who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened, wherein if a bhikkhu dwells diligent, ardent, and resolute, his unliberated mind comes to be liberated, his undestroyed taints come to be destroyed, and he attains the supreme security from bondage that he had not attained before.

original: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe…
analyzed: puna capara gahapati bhikkhu vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā ajjhattam sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvam a vitakkam a vicāram samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam pe
translated: “Again, with the stilling of applied and sustained thought, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the second jhana…

original: tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe…🔽catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: tatiyam jhānam 🔽catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: the third jhana…🔽the fourth jhana, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity.

original: So iti paṭisañcikkhati:🔽‘idampi kho catutthaṁ jhānaṁ abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ’.
analyzed: saḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati  idam api kho catuttham jhānam
translated: He considers this:🔽‘This fourth jhāna is conditioned and volitionally produced.

original: ‘Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: yam kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhatam abhisañcetayitam tat aniccam nirodha dhammanti pajānāti
translated: Whatever is conditioned and volitionally produced is subject to destruction, subject to cessation.’

original: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti;
analyzed: saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti
translated: Standing upon that, he reaches the destruction of the taints.

original: no ce āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
analyzed: no ce āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti tena iva dhamma rāgena tāya dhamma nandiyā pañcannam orambhāgiyānam sayojanānam parikkhayā opapātikaḥ hoti tattha parinibbāyī an āvatti dhammo tasmā lokā
translated: But if he does not reach the destruction of the taints, then because of that desire for the Dhamma, that delight in the Dhamma, with the destruction of the five lower fetters he becomes one due to reappear spontaneously in the Pure Abodes and there attain final Nibbana without ever returning from that world.

original: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena ekadhammo🔽sammadakkhāto, yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato avimuttaṁ🔽vā cittaṁ vimuccati aparikkhīṇā vā āsavā parikkhayaṁ gacchanti, ananuppattaṁ vā anuttaraṁ
analyzed: ayam pi kho gahapati tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena eka dhammaḥ  sammad akkhātaḥ yattha bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharataḥ avimutta  vā cittam vimuccati a parikkhīṇāḥ vā āsavāḥ parikkhayam gacchanti an anuppattam vā anuttara
translated: This, householder, is the other one thing

original: yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇāti.
analyzed: yogakkhemam anupāpuṇāti
translated: that was proclaimed by the Blessed One who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened, wherein if a bhikkhu dwells diligent, ardent, and resolute, his unliberated mind comes to be liberated, his undestroyed taints come to be destroyed, and he attains the supreme security from bondage that he had not attained before.

original: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati🔽tathā dutiyaṁ tathā tatiyaṁ tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya
analyzed: puna capara gahapati bhikkhu mettā sahagatena cetasā ekam disam pharitvā viharati  tathā dutiyam tathā tatiyam tathā catutthaḥ iti uddham adhas tiriyam sabbadhi sabbattatāya
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu abides pervading one quarter with a mind imbued with loving-kindness,🔽abundant, exalted, immeasurable, without hostility, and without ill will,

original: sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati vipulena mahaggatena🔽appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
analyzed: sabbāvantam lokam mettā sahagatena cetasā ekam disam pharitvā viharati vipulena mahaggatena  appamāṇena averena a byāpajjena pharitvā viharati
translated: focusing on one quarter, then a second, then a third, then a fourth. Thus above, below, across, and everywhere, and to all as to himself, he abides pervading the all-encompassing world with a mind imbued with loving-kindness, abundant, exalted, immeasurable, without hostility, and without ill will.

original: So iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: saḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: He considers this and understands it thus:

original: ‘ayampi kho mettā cetovimutti abhisaṅkhatā abhisañcetayitā’.
analyzed: ayam pi kho mettā cetaḥ vimutti abhisaṅkhatā abhisañcetayitā
translated: ‘This deliverance of mind through loving-kindness is conditioned and volitionally produced.

original: ‘Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: yam kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhatam abhisañcetayitam tat aniccam nirodha dhammanti pajānāti
translated: But whatever is conditioned and volitionally produced is impermanent, subject to cessation.’

original: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti;
analyzed: saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti
translated: Standing upon that, he attains the destruction of the taints.🔽Or alternatively, he achieves the heart’s release.

original: no ce āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
analyzed: no ce āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti tena iva dhamma rāgena tāya dhamma nandiyā pañcannam orambhāgiyānam sayojanānam parikkhayā opapātikaḥ hoti tattha parinibbāyī an āvatti dhammo tasmā lokā
translated: If he does not attain the destruction of the taints, then because of that desire for the Dhamma, that delight in the Dhamma, with the destruction of the five lower fetters he becomes one due to reappear spontaneously in the Pure Abodes and there attain final Nibbana without ever returning from that world.

original: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā …pe… ananuppattaṁ vā anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇāti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho gahapati tena bhagavatā jānatā pe ananuppattam vā anuttaram yogakkhemam anupāpuṇāti
translated: This too is a fruit of the contemplative life, visible here and now, more excellent than the previous ones.

original: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu karuṇāsahagatena cetasā …pe…
analyzed: puna capara gahapati bhikkhu karuṇā sahagatena cetasā pe
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu abides pervading one quarter with a mind imbued with compassion…

original: muditāsahagatena cetasā …pe…🔽upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati tathā dutiyaṁ tathā tatiyaṁ tathā catutthaṁ.
analyzed: muditā sahagatena cetasā pe  upekkhā sahagatena cetasā ekam disam pharitvā viharati tathā dutiyam tathā tatiyam tathā catuttha
translated: with a mind imbued with appreciative joy…

original: Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
analyzed: iti uddham adhas tiriyam sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantam lokam upekkhā sahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena a byāpajjena pharitvā viharati
translated: with a mind imbued with equanimity, likewise the second, likewise the third, likewise the fourth; so above, below, around, and everywhere, and to all as to himself, he abides pervading the all-encompassing world with a mind imbued with equanimity, abundant, exalted, immeasurable, without hostility and without ill will.

original: So iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: saḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: He considers thus:

original: ‘ayampi kho upekkhācetovimutti abhisaṅkhatā abhisañcetayitā’.
analyzed: ayam pi kho upekkhā cetaḥ vimutti abhisaṅkhatā abhisañcetayitā
translated: ‘This liberation of mind by equanimity is created and concocted.’

original: ‘Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: yam kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhatam abhisañcetayitam tat aniccam nirodha dhammanti pajānāti
translated: He understands: ‘Whatever is created and concocted is anicca, subject to cessation.’

original: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti;
analyzed: saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti
translated: Abiding in that, he attains the destruction of the taints.

original: no ce āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
analyzed: no ce āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti tena iva dhamma rāgena tāya dhamma nandiyā pañcannam orambhāgiyānam sayojanānam parikkhayā opapātikaḥ hoti tattha parinibbāyī an āvatti dhammo tasmā lokā
translated: If he does not attain the destruction of the taints, then because of that desire for the Dhamma, that delight in the Dhamma, with the destruction of the five lower fetters he becomes one due to reappear spontaneously in the Pure Abodes and there attain final Nibbana without ever returning from that world.

original: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā …pe… ananuppattaṁ vā anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇāti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho gahapati tena bhagavatā jānatā pe ananuppattam vā anuttaram yogakkhemam anupāpuṇāti
translated: This too is a fruit of the contemplative life, visible here and now, more excellent than the previous ones and more sublime.

original: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara gahapati bhikkhu sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ ti ākāsānañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, with the complete surmounting of perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of sensory impact, with non-attention to perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite,’ a bhikkhu enters and dwells in the base of the infinity of space.

original: So iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: saḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: He considers this and understands it thus:

original: ‘ayampi kho ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpatti abhisaṅkhatā abhisañcetayitā’.
analyzed: ayam pi kho ākāsa anañcāyatana samāpatti abhisaṅkhatā abhisañcetayitā
translated: ‘This base of the infinity of space is also a fabrication, a construction.’

original: ‘Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: yam kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhatam abhisañcetayitam tat aniccam nirodha dhammanti pajānāti
translated: He understands: ‘Whatever is fabricated and constructed is impermanent, subject to cessation.’

original: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti;
analyzed: saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti
translated: Abiding in that, he attains the destruction of the taints.

original: no ce āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
analyzed: no ce āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti tena iva dhamma rāgena tāya dhamma nandiyā pañcannam orambhāgiyānam sayojanānam parikkhayā opapātikaḥ hoti tattha parinibbāyī an āvatti dhammo tasmā lokā
translated: If he does not attain the destruction of the taints, then because of that desire for the Dhamma, that delight in the Dhamma, with the destruction of the five lower fetters he becomes one due to reappear spontaneously in the Pure Abodes and there attain final Nibbana without ever returning from that world.

original: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā …pe… ananuppattaṁ vā anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇāti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho gahapati tena bhagavatā jānatā pe ananuppattam vā anuttaram yogakkhemam anupāpuṇāti
translated: This too is a fruit of the contemplative life, visible here and now, more excellent than the previous ones and more sublime.

original: Puna caparaṁ, gahapati, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe…
analyzed: puna capara gahapati bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati pe
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu, by completely surmounting the base of the infinity of space, ‘consciousness is infinite,’ enters and dwells in the base of the infinity of consciousness. …

original: sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sabbasas viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: He completely surmounts the base of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing.’ He enters and remains in the base of nothingness.

original: So iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: saḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: He considers this and understands:

original: ‘ayampi kho ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpatti abhisaṅkhatā abhisañcetayitā’.
analyzed: ayam pi kho ākiñcaññāyatana samāpatti abhisaṅkhatā abhisañcetayitā
translated: ‘This attainment of the base of nothingness is fabricated and intended.’

original: ‘Yaṁ kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhataṁ abhisañcetayitaṁ tadaniccaṁ nirodhadhamman’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: yam kho pana kiñci abhisaṅkhatam abhisañcetayitam tat aniccam nirodha dhammanti pajānāti
translated: He understands: ‘Whatever is fabricated and intended is anicca, subject to cessation.’

original: So tattha ṭhito āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti;
analyzed: saḥ tattha ṭhitaḥ āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti
translated: Abiding in that, he attains the destruction of the taints.

original: no ce āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇāti, teneva dhammarāgena tāya dhammanandiyā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
analyzed: no ce āsavānam khayam pāpuṇāti tena iva dhamma rāgena tāya dhamma nandiyā pañcannam orambhāgiyānam sayojanānam parikkhayā opapātikaḥ hoti tattha parinibbāyī an āvatti dhammo tasmā lokā
translated: If he does not attain the destruction of the taints, then because of that desire, that delight, and that longing, he is reborn in the base of nothingness.

original: Ayampi kho, gahapati, tena bhagavatā jānatā …pe… ananuppattaṁ vā anuttaraṁ yogakkhemaṁ anupāpuṇātī”ti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho gahapati tena bhagavatā jānatā pe ananuppattam vā anuttaram yogakkhemam anupāpuṇāti iti
translated: This, householder, is the other way of contact through which a person—with the breakup of the body, after death—reappears in the base of nothingness.

original: Evaṁ vutte dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte dasamaḥ gahapati aṭṭhaka nāgaraḥ āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, the householder Dasama of Atthakanagara said to Ven. Ānanda:

original: “seyyathāpi, bhante ānanda, puriso ekaṁ nidhimukhaṁ gavesanto sakideva ekādasa nidhimukhāni adhigaccheyya;
analyzed: sa iyyathā api bhante ānanda purisaḥ ekam nidhi mukham gavesantaḥ sakidevaḥ ekādasa nidhi mukhāni adhigaccheyya
translated: “Just as if a man looking for one entrance to a hidden treasure were at the same time to find eleven entrances to it,

original: evamevaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, ekaṁ amatadvāraṁ gavesanto sakideva ekādasa amatadvārāni alatthaṁ sevanāya.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhante, purisassa agāraṁ ekādasa dvāraṁ. So tasmiṁ agāre āditte ekamekenapi dvārena sakkuṇeyya attānaṁ sotthiṁ kātuṁ;
analyzed: evam evam kho aha bhante ekam amata dvāram gavesantaḥ sakidevaḥ ekādasa amata dvārāni alattham sevanāya  seyyathā api bhante purisassa agāram ekādasa dvāra saḥ tasmin agāre āditte ekam ekena api dvārena sakkuṇeyya attānam sotthim kātu
translated: so too, while I was seeking one door to the Deathless, I found eleven doors to the Deathless, which I now enjoy.🔽Just as if there were a house with eleven doors and a man inside the house were to think, ‘Let me escape from this house through such and such a door,’ and then he were to do so,

original: evamevaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, imesaṁ ekādasannaṁ amatadvārānaṁ ekamekenapi amatadvārena sakkuṇissāmi attānaṁ sotthiṁ kātuṁ.
analyzed: evam evam kho aha bhante imesam ekādasannam amatadvārānam ekam ekena api amatadvārena sakkuṇissāmi attānam sotthim kātu
translated: so too, I can escape from this world through any one of these eleven doors to the Deathless.

original: Ime hi nāma, bhante, aññatitthiyā ācariyassa ācariyadhanaṁ pariyesissanti.
analyzed: ime hi nāma bhante añña titthiyāḥ ācariyassa ācariya dhanam pariyesissanti
translated: “Venerable sir, if the wanderers of other sects were to seek the teacher’s fee for the teacher,

original: Kiṁ panāhaṁ āyasmato ānandassa pūjaṁ na karissāmī”ti.
analyzed: kim pana aham āyasmataḥ ānandassa pūjam na karissāmi iti
translated: how much more should I do so!”

original: Atha kho dasamo gahapati aṭṭhakanāgaro vesālikañca pāṭaliputtakañca bhikkhusaṅghaṁ sannipātāpetvā paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
analyzed: atha kho dasamaḥ gahapati aṭṭhaka nāgaraḥ vesālikam ca pāṭaliputtakam ca bhikkhu saṅgham sannipātāpetvā paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi
translated: Then the householder Dasama of the Aṭṭaka clan, after gathering the Saṅgha of monks from Vesālī and Pāṭaliputta, served and satisfied them with his own hand with excellent staple and non-staple food.

original: Ekamekañca bhikkhuṁ paccekaṁ dussayugena acchādesi, āyasmantañca ānandaṁ ticīvarena.
analyzed: ekam ekam ca bhikkhum paccekam dussa yugena acchādesi āyasmantam ca ānandam ti cīvarena
translated: And he gave a set of two robes to each monk, and to Ven. Ānanda, three.

original: Āyasmato ānandassa pañcasataṁ vihāraṁ kārāpesīti.
analyzed: āyasmataḥ ānandassa pañca satam vihāram kārāpesi iti
translated: And he had a dwelling built for Ven. Ānanda worth five hundred.

original: Chaṭṭhaṁ.
analyzed: chaṭṭha
translated: The sixth .

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 11.17🔽2. Anussativagga
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya  anussati vagga
translated: The Book of the Elevens

original: Gopālasutta
analyzed: gopālasutta
translated: The Cowherds

original: “Ekādasahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako abhabbo gogaṇaṁ pariharituṁ phātiṁ kātuṁ.
analyzed: ekādasahi bhikkhave aṅgehi samannāgataḥ gopālakaḥ abhabbaḥ go gaṇam pariharitum phātim kātu
translated: “Monks, a cowherd endowed with eleven qualities is incapable of looking after a herd of cattle for rearing & growth.

original: Katamehi ekādasahi?🔽Idha, bhikkhave, gopālako na rūpaññū hoti, na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti, na āsāṭikaṁ hāretā
analyzed: katamehi ekādaśahi  idha bhikkhave gopālakaḥ na rūpa ññū hoti na lakkhaṇa kusalaḥ hoti na āsāṭikam hāretā
translated: Endowed with which eleven?

original: hoti, na vaṇaṁ paṭicchādetā hoti, na dhūmaṁ kattā hoti, na titthaṁ jānāti, na pītaṁ
analyzed: hoti na vaṇam paṭicchādetā hoti na dhūmam kattā hoti na tittham jānāti na pīta
translated: There is the case where the cowherd is not skilled in forms, is not skilled in characteristics, does not remove dust & dirt, does not tend wounds, does not fumigate, does not know the ford, does not know the watering place, does not know what it is to have drunk,🔽does not know the road, does not know the pasture, and is not skilled in loading.

original: jānāti, na vīthiṁ jānāti, na gocarakusalo hoti, anavasesadohī ca hoti, ye te usabhā🔽gopitaro gopariṇāyakā te na atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti.
analyzed: jānāti na vīthim jānāti na gocara kusalaḥ hoti anavasesa dohī ca hoti ye te usabhā  go pitaraḥ go pariṇāyakā te na atireka pūjāya pūjetā
translated: he doesn’t know the road, he’s not skilled in pastures, he doesn’t know what it is to have drunk, and he doesn’t respect the bulls, the fathers and leaders of the herd.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako abhabbo gogaṇaṁ pariharituṁ phātiṁ kātuṁ.
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave ekādasahi aṅgehi samannāgataḥ gopālakaḥ abhabbaḥ go gaṇam pariharitum phātim kātu
translated: “A cowherd with these eleven factors is incapable of keeping and rearing a herd of cattle.

original: Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu abhabbo imasmiṁ dhammavinaye vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjituṁ.
analyzed: evam evam kho bhikkhave ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu abhabbaḥ imasmin dhamma vinaye vuddhim virūḷhim vepullam āpajjitu
translated: In the same way, a monk with eleven qualities is incapable of growth, increase, and abundance in this Dhamma and Discipline.

original: Katamehi ekādasahi?
analyzed: katamehi ekādaśahi
translated: With what eleven?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na rūpaññū hoti, na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti, na āsāṭikaṁ hāretā🔽hoti, na vaṇaṁ paṭicchādetā hoti, na dhūmaṁ kattā hoti, na titthaṁ jānāti, na pītaṁ
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu na rūpa ññū hoti na lakkhaṇa kusalaḥ hoti na āsāṭikam hāretā  hoti na vaṇam paṭicchādetā hoti na dhūmam kattā hoti na tittham jānāti na pīta
translated: There is the case where a monk is not skilled in (the characteristics that are) form, not skilled in (the characteristics that are) formless, not skilled in (the characteristics that are) internal, not skilled in (the characteristics that are) external, not skilled in (the characteristics that are) both internal and external.

original: jānāti, na vīthiṁ jānāti, na gocarakusalo hoti, anavasesadohī ca hoti, ye te bhikkhū
analyzed: jānāti na vīthim jānāti na gocara kusalaḥ hoti anavasesa dohī ca hoti ye te bhikkhū
translated: He doesn’t know the road, he doesn’t know the ford, he doesn’t know what it is to have drunk, he doesn’t know the pasture, he doesn’t know the watering place, he doesn’t know the track, he doesn’t respect the senior monks of long-standing and long since gone forth, who have long been noble ones in the Lord Buddha’s dispensation, who are long-standing true disciples.

original: therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā te na atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti.
analyzed: therā rattaññū cira pabbajitā saṅgha pitaro saṅgha pariṇāyakā te na atireka pūjāya pūjetā hoti
translated: He doesn’t give extra service to the senior monks, the long-standing monks, the regular monks.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na rūpaññū hoti?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu na rūpa ññū hoti
translated: “And how is a monk not skilled in what is possible and what is impossible?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yaṁ kiñci rūpaṁ (…) ‘cattāri mahābhūtāni, catunnañca mahābhūtānaṁ upādāyarūpan’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu yam kiñci rūpam cattāri mahābhūtāni catunnam ca mahābhūtānam upādāya rūpanti yathābhūtam na pajānāti
translated: It’s when a monk doesn’t understand what is possible and what is impossible in the world.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na rūpaññū hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na rūpa ññū hoti
translated: That’s how a monk is not skilled in what is possible and what is impossible.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu na lakkhaṇa kusalaḥ hoti
translated: “And how is a monk not skilled in traits?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘kammalakkhaṇo bālo, kammalakkhaṇo paṇḍito’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu kamma lakkhaṇaḥ bālaḥ kamma lakkhaṇaḥ paṇḍitaḥ iti yathābhūtam na ppajānāti
translated: It’s when a monk doesn’t understand the traits of a fool and the traits of a wise person.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na lakkhaṇakusalo hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na lakkhaṇa kusalaḥ hoti
translated: That’s how a monk is not skilled in traits.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na āsāṭikaṁ hāretā hoti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu na āsāṭikam hāretā hoti
translated: “And how does a monk not remove the dart?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṁ kāmavitakkaṁ adhivāseti nappajahati na vinodeti na byantīkaroti na anabhāvaṁ gameti, uppannaṁ byāpādavitakkaṁ … uppannaṁ vihiṁsāvitakkaṁ …
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu uppannam kāma vitakkam adhivāseti na pajahati na vinodeti na byantīkaroti na anabhāvam gameti uppannam byāpāda vitakkam uppannam vihisā vitakkam
translated: He tolerates an arisen thought of ill-will. He doesn’t abandon it, destroy it, dispel it, or wipe it out of existence.🔽He tolerates an arisen thought of harmfulness. He doesn’t abandon it, destroy it, dispel it, or wipe it out of existence.

original: uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme adhivāseti nappajahati na vinodeti na byantīkaroti na anabhāvaṁ gameti.
analyzed: uppanna uppanne pāpake akusale dhamme adhivāseti na pajahati na vinodeti na byantīkaroti na anabhāvam gameti
translated: He tolerates arisen evil, unskillful thoughts. He doesn’t abandon them, destroy them, dispel them, or wipe them out of existence.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na āsāṭikaṁ hāretā hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na āsāṭikam hāretā hoti
translated: This is how a monk doesn’t pull out the dart.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na vaṇaṁ paṭicchādetā hoti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu na vaṇam paṭicchādetā hoti
translated: “And how does a monk not cover the wound?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā nimittaggāhī hoti anubyañjanaggāhī;🔽yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā nimitta ggāhī hoti anubyañjana ggāhī  yatvā adhikaraṇam enam cakkhu indriyam asavutam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: There is the case where a monk, on seeing a form via the eye, is intent on pleasing forms, is intent on detesting unpleasing forms, and is overwhelmed with regard to forms that are the basis for passion.🔽He doesn’t practice for disenchantment with regard to the property of form, for dispassion, for cessation, for letting go.🔽He doesn’t practice for disenchantment with regard to the property of feeling, for dispassion, for cessation, for letting go.🔽He doesn’t practice for disenchantment with regard to the property of perception, for dispassion, for cessation, for letting go.🔽He doesn’t practice for disenchantment with regard to the property of fabrication, for dispassion, for cessation, for letting go.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya na paṭipajjati; na rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ,
analyzed: dhammā anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya na paṭipajjati na rakkhati cakkhu indriya
translated: He doesn’t practice for disenchantment with regard to the property of consciousness, for dispassion, for cessation, for letting go.

original: cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ nāpajjati.🔽Sotena saddaṁ sutvā …
analyzed: cakkhu indriye savaram na āpajjati 🔽sotena saddam sutvā
translated: This is how a monk doesn’t cover the wound.

original: ghānena gandhaṁ ghāyitvā …
analyzed: ghānena gandham ghāyitvā
translated: Having smelt an odour with the nose …

original: jivhāya rasaṁ sāyitvā …
analyzed: jivhāya rasam sāyitvā
translated: Having tasted a flavour with the tongue …

original: kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ phusitvā …
analyzed: kāyena phoṭṭhabbam phusitvā
translated: Having felt an object with the body …

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya nimittaggāhī hoti anubyañjanaggāhī;
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya nimitta ggāhī hoti anubyañjana ggāhī
translated: Having cognized a mind-object with the mind, he grasps at significant features and seizes on the general configuration.

original: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: yatvā adhikaraṇam enam man indriyam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: If he lives with the mind-faculty unrestrained, evil unwholesome states of longing and dejection invade him.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya na paṭipajjati; na rakkhati manindriyaṁ, manindriye saṁvaraṁ nāpajjati.
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya na paṭipajjati na rakkhati manindriya manindriye savaram na āpajjati
translated: He does not practise restraint, he does not guard the mind-faculty; he lives with the mind-faculty unrestrained.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na vaṇaṁ paṭicchādetā hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na vaṇam paṭicchādetā hoti
translated: That is how a bhikkhu does not close the gate.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na dhūmaṁ kattā hoti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu na dhūmam kattā hoti
translated: “And how does a bhikkhu not know the ford?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena paresaṁ desetā hoti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu na yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam vitthārena paresam desetā hoti
translated: Here, a bhikkhu does not teach others in detail the Dhamma as he has learned it and mastered it.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na dhūmaṁ kattā hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na dhūmam kattā hoti
translated: That is how a bhikkhu does not know the ford.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na titthaṁ jānāti?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu na tittham jānāti
translated: “And how does a bhikkhu not know moderation in eating?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū bahussutā āgatāgamā dhammadharā vinayadharā mātikādharā, te kālena kālaṁ upasaṅkamitvā na paripucchati na paripañhati:
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū bahu ssutāḥ āgata āgamāḥ dhamma dharāḥ vinaya dharāḥ mātikā dharā te kālena kālam upasaṅkamitvā na paripucchati na paripañhati
translated: There is the case where a monk does not, in timely fashion, approach those monks who are elders, experienced, with developed view, and inquire of them:🔽

original: ‘idaṁ, bhante, kathaṁ, imassa ko attho’ti?
analyzed: ida bhante katha imassa kaḥ atthaḥ ti
translated: There is the case where a monk, when the monks who are skilled in the phrasing, skilled in the progression of the Monastic Law, and well-versed in the Monastic Law are speaking, doesn’t ask them, ‘How is this, venerable sir? What is the meaning of this?’

original: Tassa te āyasmanto avivaṭañceva na vivaranti, anuttānīkatañca na uttānīkaronti, anekavihitesu ca kaṅkhāṭhāniyesu dhammesu kaṅkhaṁ na paṭivinodenti.
analyzed: tassa te āyasmantaḥ a vivaṭam ca iva na vivaranti an uttānīkatam ca na uttānīkaronti aneka vihitesu ca kaṅkhāṭhāniyesu dhammesu kaṅkham na paṭivinodenti
translated: So the venerables don’t reveal to him what hasn’t been revealed, don’t make plain what hasn’t been made plain, don’t dispel his doubts concerning the many & diverse kinds of mental phenomena that give rise to doubts.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na titthaṁ jānāti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na tittham jānāti
translated: This is how a monk doesn’t know the ford.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na pītaṁ jānāti?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu na pītam jānāti
translated: “And how does a monk not know what it is to have drunk?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye desiyamāne na labhati atthavedaṁ, na labhati dhammavedaṁ, na labhati dhammūpasaṁhitaṁ pāmojjaṁ.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu tathāgata ppavedite dhamma vinaye desiyamāne na labhati attha veda na labhati dhamma veda na labhati dhamma upasahitam pāmojja
translated: There is the case where a monk, when the Dhamma & Vinaya proclaimed by the Tathāgata is being taught, doesn’t gain inspiration in the meaning, doesn’t gain inspiration in the Dhamma, doesn’t find solace in the meaning, doesn’t find solace in the Dhamma.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na pītaṁ jānāti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na pītam jānāti
translated: This is how a monk doesn’t know what it is to have drunk.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na vīthiṁ jānāti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu na vīthim jānāti
translated: “And how does a monk not know the road?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikaṁ maggaṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam maggam yathābhūtam na ppajānāti
translated: There is the case where a monk does not discern, as it actually is, the noble eightfold path.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na vīthiṁ jānāti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na vīthim jānāti
translated: This is how a monk does not know the path.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na gocarakusalo hoti?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu na gocara kusalaḥ hoti
translated: “And how is a monk not skilled in pastures?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu cattāraḥ satipaṭṭhāne yathābhūtam na ppajānāti
translated: There is the case where a monk does not discern, as they actually are, the four establishings of mindfulness.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na gocarakusalo hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu na gocara kusalaḥ hoti
translated: This is how a monk is not skilled in pastures.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anavasesadohī hoti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu anavasesa dohī hoti
translated: “And how does a monk milk dry?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṁ saddhā gahapatikā abhihaṭṭhuṁ pavārenti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi. Tatra bhikkhu mattaṁ na jānāti paṭiggahaṇāya.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhum saddhāḥ gahapatikāḥ abhihaṭṭhum pavārenti cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhārehi tatra bhikkhu mattam na jānāti paṭiggahaṇāya
translated: There is the case where faithful householders invite a monk, ‘Please, venerable sir, accept from me robes, almsfood, lodgings, & medicinal requisites for curing illness.’ The monk accepts.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anavasesadohī hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu anavasesa dohī hoti
translated: This is how a monk milks dry.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā, te na atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū therāḥ rattaññū cira pabbajitā saṅgha pitaraḥ saṅgha pariṇāyakā te na atireka pūjāya pūjetā hoti
translated: “And how does a monk not revere the Teacher?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro🔽saṅghapariṇāyakā, tesu na mettaṁ kāyakammaṁ paccupaṭṭhāpeti āvi ceva raho ca, na🔽mettaṁ vacīkammaṁ … na mettaṁ manokammaṁ paccupaṭṭhāpeti āvi ceva raho ca.🔽Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā, na te atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū therāḥ rattaññū cira pabbajitāḥ saṅgha pitaro  saṅgha pariṇāyakā tesu na mettam kāya kammam paccupaṭṭhāpeti āvi ca iva raho ca na  mettam vacī kammam na mettam manaḥ kammam paccupaṭṭhāpeti āvi ca iva raho ca  evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu ye te bhikkhū therāḥ rattaññū cira pabbajitāḥ saṅgha pitaraḥ saṅgha pariṇāyakāḥ na te atireka pūjāya pūjetā hoti
translated: There is the case where a monk does not provide bodily acts of good will, does not provide verbal acts of good will, does not provide mental acts of good will toward the elder monks, the middle monks, & the junior monks.🔽This is how a monk does not provide superior service to those elder monks, those middle monks, & those junior monks.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu abhabbo imasmiṁ dhammavinaye vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjituṁ.
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu abhabbaḥ imasmin dhamma vinaye vuddhim virūḷhim vepullam āpajjitu
translated: “Endowed with these eleven qualities, a monk is incapable of growth, increase, or abundance in this Dhamma-Vinaya.

original: Ekādasahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako bhabbo gogaṇaṁ pariharituṁ phātiṁ kātuṁ.
analyzed: ekādasahi bhikkhave aṅgehi samannāgataḥ gopālakaḥ bhabbaḥ go gaṇam pariharitum phātim kātu
translated: “A cowherd endowed with eleven qualities is capable of looking after a herd so that it prospers & grows.

original: Katamehi ekādasahi?
analyzed: katamehi ekādaśahi
translated: “Endowed with what eleven qualities?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, gopālako rūpaññū hoti, lakkhaṇakusalo hoti, āsāṭikaṁ hāretā hoti,
analyzed: idha bhikkhave gopālakaḥ rūpa ññū hoti lakkhaṇa kusalaḥ hoti āsāṭikam hāretā hoti
translated: “There is the case where the cowherd is skilled in forms, skilled in characteristics, skilled in color, skilled in voice, skilled in manner, skilled in pastures, skilled in watering places, skilled in judging when the cattle have had enough, skilled in protecting the afflicted, skilled in nursing the sick, and skilled in treating wounds.

original: vaṇaṁ paṭicchādetā hoti, dhūmaṁ kattā hoti, titthaṁ jānāti, pītaṁ jānāti, vīthiṁ🔽jānāti, gocarakusalo hoti, sāvasesadohī ca hoti, ye te usabhā gopitaro gopariṇāyakā
analyzed: vaṇam paṭicchādetā hoti dhūmam kattā hoti tittham jānāti pītam jānāti vīthi  jānāti gocara kusalaḥ hoti sa avasesa dohī ca hoti ye te usabhāḥ go pitaraḥ go pariṇāyakā
translated: he covers the wounds; he knows the right path; he knows the ford; he knows what it is to have drunk;

original: te atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti—
analyzed: te atireka pūjāya pūjetā ha iti
translated: he knows the route; he is skilled in pastures; he knows what it is to have enough or to have had enough; and he respects, esteems, venerates, and honours the bulls, the leaders of the herd, the bull-wiskers.

original: imehi kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi aṅgehi samannāgato gopālako bhabbo gogaṇaṁ pariharituṁ phātiṁ kātuṁ.
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave ekādasahi aṅgehi samannāgataḥ gopālakaḥ bhabbaḥ go gaṇam pariharitum phātim kātu
translated: A cowherd with these eleven factors can look after a herd of cattle and make it grow.

original: Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu bhabbo imasmiṁ dhammavinaye vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjituṁ.
analyzed: evam evam kho bhikkhave ekādasahi dhammehi samannāgataḥ bhikkhu bhabbaḥ imasmin dhamma vinaye vuddhim virūḷhim vepullam āpajjitu
translated: In the same way, a monk with eleven qualities can look after a Sangha of monks and make it grow.

original: Katamehi ekādasahi?
analyzed: katamehi ekādaśahi
translated: With what eleven?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rūpaññū hoti, lakkhaṇakusalo hoti, āsāṭikaṁ hāretā hoti,🔽vaṇaṁ paṭicchādetā hoti, dhūmaṁ kattā hoti, titthaṁ jānāti, pītaṁ jānāti, vīthiṁ
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu rūpa ññū hoti lakkhaṇa kusalaḥ hoti āsāṭikam hāretā hoti  vaṇam paṭicchādetā hoti dhūmam kattā hoti tittham jānāti pītam jānāti vīthi
translated: Here a monk knows what is the true nature of form, he knows the danger in form, he knows the escape from form;🔽he covers the wounds; he knows the right path; he knows the ford; he knows what it is to have drunk;

original: jānāti, gocarakusalo hoti, sāvasesadohī ca hoti, ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā
analyzed: jānāti gocara kusalaḥ hoti sa avasesa dohī ca hoti ye te bhikkhū therāḥ rattaññū cira pabbajitā
translated: he knows the route; he is skilled in pastures; he knows what it is to have enough or to have had enough; and he respects, esteems, venerates, and honours the senior monks, those with seniority, and the most senior monks.

original: saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā te atirekapūjāya pūjetā hoti.
analyzed: saṅgha pitaraḥ saṅgha pariṇāyakā te atireka pūjāya pūjetā hoti
translated: and the Sangha is the father and mother of the Sangha.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rūpaññū hoti?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu rūpa ññū hoti
translated: “And how is a monk skilled in forms?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yaṁ kiñci rūpaṁ ‘cattāri mahābhūtāni, catunnañca mahābhūtānaṁ upādāyarūpan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu yam kiñci rūpam cattāri mahābhūtāni catunnam ca mahābhūtānam yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: It’s when a monk understands as it really is: ‘Whatever is material form is all four great elements and the form derived from the four great elements.’

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rūpaññū hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu rūpa ññū hoti
translated: That’s how a monk is skilled in forms.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu lakkhaṇakusalo hoti?
analyzed: kathañca bhikkhave bhikkhu lakkhaṇa kusalaḥ hoti
translated: “And how is a monk skilled in characteristics?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘kammalakkhaṇo bālo, kammalakkhaṇo paṇḍito’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu kamma lakkhaṇaḥ bālaḥ kamma lakkhaṇaḥ paṇḍitaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: It’s when a monk understands as it really is: ‘A fool is characterized by his actions; a wise man is characterized by his actions.’

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu lakkhaṇakusalo hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu lakkhaṇa kusalaḥ hoti
translated: That’s how a monk is skilled in characteristics.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āsāṭikaṁ hāretā hoti?🔽Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṁ kāmavitakkaṁ nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu āsāṭikam hāretā hoti  idha bhikkhave bhikkhu uppannam kāma vitakkam na adhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti
translated: “And how does a monk pull out the dart?

original: anabhāvaṁ gameti, uppannaṁ byāpādavitakkaṁ … uppannaṁ vihiṁsāvitakkaṁ … uppannuppanne
analyzed: anabhāvam gama iti uppannam byāpāda vitakkam uppannam vihisā vitakkam uppanna uppanne
translated: It’s when a monk doesn’t consent to thoughts of sensual desire that have arisen, and he abandons them, eliminates them, gets rid of them, and obliterates them. He doesn’t consent to thoughts of ill will …🔽He doesn’t consent to thoughts of harming …

original: pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṁ gameti.
analyzed: pāpake akusale dhamme na adhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvam gameti
translated: he does not tolerate an arisen bad unwholesome state; he abandons it, destroys it, dispels it, and wipes it out of existence.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āsāṭikaṁ hāretā hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu āsāṭikam hāretā hoti
translated: It is in such a way, bhikkhus, that a bhikkhu extracts the stake of stinginess.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vaṇaṁ paṭicchādetā hoti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu vaṇam paṭicchādetā hoti
translated: “And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu heal the split in the bamboo?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī;🔽yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā na nimitta ggāhī hoti na anubyañjana ggāhī  yatvā adhikaraṇam enam cakkhu indriyam asavutam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
